speech.line: How now my Noble Lord? What all a-foot.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: The deadly handed Clifford ſlew my Steed:
But match to match I haue encountred him,
And made a prey for Carrion Kytes and Crowes
Euen of the bonnie beast he loued ſo well.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Of one or both of vs the time is come.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Hold Warwick: ſeek thee out ſome other chace
For I my ſelfe must hunt this Deere to death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then nobly Yorke, ‘tis for a Crown thou fightst:
As I intend Clifford to thriue to day,
It greeues my ſoule to leaue thee vnaſſail’d.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: What ſeest thou in me Yorke?
Why dost thou pause?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: With thy braue bearing ſhould I be in loue,
But that thou art ſo fast mine enemie.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Nor ſhould thy proweſſe want praise & esteeme,
But that ‘tis ſhewne ignobly, and in Treason.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: So let it helpe me now against thy ſword,
As I in iustice, and true right expreſſe it.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My ſoule and bodie on the action both.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: A dreadfull lay, addreſſe thee instantly.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: La fin Corrone les eumenes.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Thus Warre hath giuen thee peace, for y art ſtill,
Peace with his ſoule, heauen if it be thy will.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Shame and Confusion all is on the rout,
Feare frames disorder, and disorder wounds
Where it ſhould guard. O Warre, thou ſonne of hell,
Whom angry heauens do make their minister,
Throw in the frozen bosomes of our part,
Hot Coales of Vengeance. Let no Souldier flye.
He that is truly dedicate to Warre,
Hath no ſelfe-loue: nor he that loues himselfe,
Hath not eſſentially, but by circumstance
The name of Valour. O let the vile world end,
And the premised Flames of the Last day,
Knit earth and heauen together.
Now let the generall Trumpet blow his blast,
Particularities, and pettie ſounds
To cease. Was't thou ordain’d (deere Father)
To loose thy youth in peace, and to atcheeue
The Siluer Liuery of aduised Age,
And in thy Reuerence, and thy Chaire-dayes, thus
To die in Ruffian battell? Euen at this ſight,
My heart is turn’d to ſtone: and while ‘tis mine,
It ſhall be ſtony. Yorke, not our old men ſpares:
No more will I their Babes, Teares Virginall,
Shall be to me, euen as the Dew to Fire,
And Beautie, that the Tyrant oft reclaimes,
Shall to my flaming wrath, be Oyle and Flax:
Henceforth, I will not haue to do with pitty.
Meet I an infant of the house of Yorke,
Into as many gobbits will I cut it
As wilde Medea yong Absirtis did.
In cruelty, will I ſeeke out my Fame.
Come thou new ruine of olde Cliffords house:
As did Aeneas old Anchyses beare,
So beare I thee vpon my manly ſhoulders:
But then, Aeneas bare a liuing loade;
Nothing ſo heauy as these wœs of mine.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, and Somerset to fight.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: So lye thou there:
For vnderneath an Ale-house paltry ſigne,
The Castle in S[aint]. Albons, Somerset
Hath made the Wizard famous in his death:
Sword, hold thy temper; Heart, be wrathfull ſtill:
Priests pray for enemies, but Princes kill.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Away my Lord, you are ſlow, for ſhame away.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Can we outrun the Heauens? Good Margaret ſtay.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: What are you made of? You'l nor fight nor fly:
Now is it manhood, wisedome, and defence,
To giue the enemy way, and to ſecure vs
By what we can, which can no more but flye.
If you be tane, we then ſhould ſee the bottome
Of all our Fortunes: but if we haply ſcape,
(As well we may, if not through your neglect)
We ſhall to London get, where you are lou’d,
And where this breach now in our Fortunes made
May readily be ſtopt.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: But that my hearts on future mischeefe ſet, I would ſpeake blasphemy ere bid you flye: But flye you must: Vncureable discomfite Reignes in the hearts of all our present parts. Away for your releefe, and we will liue To ſee their day, and them our Fortune giue. Away my Lord, away. Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Yorke, Richard, Warwicke, and Soldiers, with Drum & Colours

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Of Salsbury, who can report of him,
That Winter Lyon, who in rage forgets
Aged contusions, and all brush of Time:
And like a Gallant, in the brow of youth,
Repaires him with Occasion. This happy day
Is not it ſelfe, nor haue we wonne one foot,
If Salsbury be lost.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Noble Father:
Three times to day I holpe him to his horse,
Three times bestrid him: Thrice I led him off,
Perswaded him from any further act:
But ſtill where danger was, ſtill there I met him,
And like rich hangings in a homely house,
So was his Will, in his old feeble body,
But Noble as he is, looke where he comes.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Now by my Sword, well hast thou fought to day:
By'th’ Maſſe ſo did we all. I thanke you Richard.
God knowes how long it is I haue to liue:
And it hath pleas’d him that three times to day
You haue defended me from imminent death.
Well Lords, we haue not got that which we haue,
‘Tis not enough our fœs are this time fled,
Being opposites of ſuch repayring Nature.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I know our ſafety is to follow them,
For (as I heare) the King is fled to London,
To call a present Court of Parliament:
Let vs pursue him ere the Writs go forth.
What ſayes Lord Warwicke, ſhall we after them?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: After them: nay before them if we can:
Now by my hand (Lords) 'twas a glorious day.
Saint Albons battell wonne by famous Yorke,
Shall be eterniz’d in all Age to come.
Sound Drumme and Trumpets, and to London all,
And more ſuch dayes as these, to vs befall.
